captions.text:
00:00
FORREST: Boy, anything that can bear hug a
man like that is a pretty big lobster.

00:06
COMM: It may look like something from a science

fiction movie, but this huge Pacific spiny
lobster weighs in at a whopping 11 and a half
pounds.

00:16
FORREST: This is an unbelievable cockroach

00:19
COMM: Forrest Galante is a 26 year old biologist

who lives in Santa Barbara, California, he
was free diving for lobsters as he has done

for the last 10 years when he made this impressive
catch

00:30
FORREST: Out in the open I stumbled upon something

that very few people in this world will ever
see and thats an almost 12 pound lobster,

although he would probably have pounds and
pounds of unbelievably scrumptious meat due

to the fact that he's a big breeder, we're
going to go ahead and put him back in the
ocean and let him continue.

00:54
COMM: However, rather than release Albert

immediately, Forrest decided to take him home
to show his family, until Forrest was able

to release him back into the ocean, he arranged
for him to stay at his local sea centre in

Santa Barbara. Based on his size and weight,
Albert was estimated to be between 60 and

70 years old and because larger lobsters are
more fertile, Forrest was determined to take
Albert somewhere he would be safe to breed.

00:21
FORREST: And so finally this big giant of

an animal is going to be released back into
the wild, somewhere where he can live out

the rest of his life, miles from anywhere
that anybody can allow to take lobsters the

Millan Marine Reserve. So I' going to pick
him up and put him in and let him loose, alright
Albert here we go my friend.

01:43
COMM: Pacific spiny lobsters this size used

to be common decades ago but due to intensive
fishing, you're now unlikely to find one over

3 pounds in weight, this makes it even more
vital that specimens this impressive remain
in the ocean

02:00
FORREST: Alright successful release of Albert
Gurther, the legendary lobster.

comments.author: Joe Vargas

comments.text:
Because 1. You can't tell how old one is unless you've had it from hatch. 
2. That's a cray- or crawfish. See the total lack of claws? Now see a total 
different species. 3. It's red. Not blue. Typical colouring for the 
species. 4. Average size on paper, lovely beastie though. And 5. Smashing 
it down into the water to depth (therefore pressure) differentials so 
quickly probably didn't do it any favours. Neither would excessive handling 
by its horns - its sensory apparatus. Want to get hauled around by your 
ears? No? That's empathy, man.

comments.author: Poodleinacan

comments.text:
+Ferris Actually, I decided to write an essay discussing this. While 
Malacostracans don't feel pain in the exact same way, they do feel 
dangerous stimuli, remember them and are averse to them. While it almost 
certainly isn't emotional pain as we know it, they certainly remember 
unpleasant experiences and actively avoid them, if only as a survival 
mechanism.

We now have a consensus that the only truly humane way to eat 
Malacostracans like Crabs and Lobsters is to kill them before cooking by 
stabbing them in the anterior and posterior ganglia, nullifying their pain 
and deactivating their senses.

comments.text:
*Giant Lobster: Biologist Discovers 70-Year-Old Crustacean - YouTube*

*' ... A biologist caught a huge 70-year-old lobster that could be one of 
the biggest catches of the year. Forrest Galante was free-diving when he 
found the huge crustacean that weighed close to 12 pounds. Due to over 
fishing and general ocean conditions, the Pacific Spiny lobster rarely 
exceeds three pounds in weight. After debating whether to toss him back or 
eat him Forrest decided he had to take the lobster back to his home in 
Santa Barbara to show his family. The family quickly decided there was no 
way they could eat the lobster so took it to a marine reserve off the coast 
of California where it was released. ... '*

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rMUYyCSNsbs#t=113﻿
